{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2011}} {{Update|date=December 2011}} {{Infobox civilian attack |title=Siege of Hama (2011) |image=Hama Al-Assy Square 29-07-2011.png |partof=[[2011 Syrian uprising]] |caption=Large protests in Al-Assy square in Hama |location= [[Hama]], Syria |target=Protesters |date=3 July 2011 â Ongoing |time= |timezone= |type= |fatalities=More than 265 citizens{{cite news|last=Karouny |first=Mariam |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/03/us-syria-idUSLDE73N02P20110603 |title=Syria intensifies assault on anti-Assad protesters |publisher=Reuters |date= 3 June 2011|accessdate=3 August 2011}}
8 policemen and 5 soldiers[http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/11/18/177893.html Scores killed as Syria requests change to Arab plan; Russia calls for ârestraintâ][http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/11/25/179163.html More civilians killed by Syrian forces; U.N. voices alarm at torture of children] Four Goverment Intelligence agentshttp://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-15809269 (Government claim) |injuries= |perps = [[Syrian Army]] }} {{Campaignbox Syrian uprising}} The '''Siege of Hama''',{{cite web|url=http://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/country-files_156/syria_295/france-and-syria_6018/political-relations_6414/syria-siege-of-hama-05.07.11_15946.html |title=France-Diplomatie |publisher=Diplomatie.gouv.fr |date= |accessdate=3 August 2011}} also known as the '''Hama Blockade''',{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/07/07/156475.html |title=Syrian protesters demand end of Hama blockade |publisher=Alarabiya.net |date=7 July 2011 |accessdate=3 August 2011}} is a major arena of the [[2011 Syrian uprising]] against president [[Bashar al-Assad]]. The city of [[Hama]], in central [[Syria]], erupted in violence on 3 June 2011 when tens of thousands of demonstrators took to the streets to express their opposition to the government. They were targeted by the secret police and military forces, and more than 50 people were killed and hundreds injured. On 1 July, with more than 400,000 protestors, Hama witnessed the largest demonstration against Bashar al-Assad.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-13988701 |title=Syria: 'Hundreds of thousands' join anti-Assad protests |publisher=BBC |date=1 July 2011 |accessdate=3 August 2011}} Two days later, Syrian tanks deployed at Hama{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/07/03/us-syria-hama-idUSTRE7620XE20110703 |title=Syrian tanks deploy at Hama after large protest |publisher=Reuters |date= 3 July 2011|accessdate=3 August 2011}} in an operation that led to more than 20 civilian deaths at the hands of Syrian security forces, and two rapes were witnessed.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/07/20117575942416758.html |title=Syrian forces in deadly assault on Hama - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=5 July 2011 |accessdate=3 August 2011}} On 31 July, the [[government of Syria]] sent the [[Syrian army]] into Hama to control protests on the eve of [[Ramadan]], as part of a nationwide crackdown, nicknamed the Ramadan Massacre.{{cite news| url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/syrias-ramadan-massacre/2011/08/01/gIQAZHCKoI_story.html | work=The Washington Post | first=Robert J. | last=Samuelson | date=2 August 2011}} At least 142 people across Syria died on that day, including over 100 in Hama alone, and 29 in [[Deir ez-Zor]]. Hundreds more have been wounded.{{cite web|author=AFP|date=31 July 2011|url=http://www.dawn.com/2011/07/31/syrian-army-kills-at-least-95-in-hama-activist.html |title=Syrian army kills at least 95 in Hama: activist|publisher=Dawn.Com |date= |accessdate=3 August 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.khaleejtimes.com/DisplayArticle09.asp?xfile=data/middleeast/2011/August/middleeast_August34.xml§ion=middleeast |title=Hama assault into second day, UN revives Syria debate |publisher=Khaleejtimes.com |date= |accessdate=3 August 2011}} By 4 August, more than 200 civilians had been killed in Hama.{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/05/world/middleeast/05syria.html?_r=1&hpw|title=Civilian Toll Is Mounting in Assault on Syrian City|date=4 August 2011|accessdate=5 August 2011|work=New York Times|publisher=The New York Times Company|first=Nada|last=Bakri}} ==Background== {{main|1964 Hama riot|April 1981 Hama massacre|Hama massacre}} Hama has been the epicenter of [[Syrian uprising]]s since the very event of the [[1963 Syrian coup d'Ã©tat|1963 Ba'athist coup]]. As early as 1964, a widescale [[1964 Hama riot|riot]], often described as [[1964 Hama riot|uprising]], broke out in the city, and was violently suppressed by the military, resulting in more than 70 citizens killed. Violence occurred once again during the 1976â1982 [[Islamic uprising in Syria]], when hundreds of Hama citizens were executed in the [[April 1981 Hama massacre|April 1981 crackdown]], whereas in February 1982, a much larger scale [[Hama massacre|massacre]] took place in Hama, following an armed and organized [[Hama massacre|uprising of Islamic groups]], centered in the city. The 1982 [[Hama massacre]] claimed the lives of some 10,000 - 25,000 Hama citizens and Islamic militants and as many as 1,000 Syrian Army personnel. ==History== ===Prelude=== Disturbances in Hama began on 3 June 2011, primarily in the city center, and on occasion in the suburbs. The Syrian security forces shot dead up to 25 people when they dispersed a demonstration by tens of locals in the city of Hama on Friday 3 June 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/n.php?n=8216at-least-25-dead8217-in-hama-syria-rallies-reach-capital-2011-06-03 |title=âAt least 25 deadâ in Hama, Syria rallies reach capital |publisher=Hurriyet Daily News |date= |accessdate=3 August 2011}} On 1 July 2011, with more than 400,000 protestors, Hama witnessed the largest demonstration against [[Bashar al-Assad]]. Soon after, Assad sacked Hama's governor.{{cite news|last=Evans |first=Dominic |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/07/02/us-syria-protests-idUSTRE7601NA20110702 |title=Syria's Assad sacks Hama governor after protests |publisher=Reuters |date= 2 July 2011|accessdate=3 August 2011}} Two days after, Syrian tanks deployed at Hama, in an operation that led to more than 20 civilians killed by the Syrian security forces and two rape cases were witnessed. ===The siege=== [[File:Hama-map.png|thumb|right|200px|A map of [[Syria]] with [[Hama]] (ÙÙØ­Ø§ÙØ¸Ø© Ø­ÙØ§Ù) [[Governorates of Syria|Governorate]] highlighted.]] {{Wikinews|More than 100 reported dead after Syrian troops move against protesters}} As the city of Hama became one of the main opposition centers of the [[2011 Syrian uprising|popular uprising]], taking place in Syria, Hama turned into a focal point of growing violence. An armed blockade was imposed on the city on 3 July. On 6 July, a surprising step was taken by the US ambassador, [[Robert Stephen Ford|Robert Ford]], when he visited Hama and declared that he will stay there till Friday. Syria reacted with anger with this visit.{{cite news|author=Martin Chulov |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jul/08/syria-condemns-us-ambassador-visit-hama |title=Syria condemns US ambassador's 'provocative' visit to Hama |publisher=guardian.co.uk |date= 8 July 2011|accessdate=3 August 2011 |location=London}} On 8 July, more than 500,000{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/07/2011780473138345.html |title='Half a million' protest on streets of Hama - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=8 July 2011 |accessdate=3 August 2011}} Syrians flooded through the city of Hama, according to activists, in what they claim was the single biggest protest yet against the embattled government of President [[Bashar al-Assad]]. Demonstrators in Hama have received the US ambassadors with flowers to express their gratitude of the visit and to reach their voices to the world. JJ Harder, the press attachÃ© of the US embassy in [[Damascus]], later told [[Al Jazeera]]: "Our ambassador Robert Ford was in Hama earlier this month, and he saw with his own eyes the violence that they are talking about. There was none. He maybe saw one teenager with a stick at a checkpoint, and the government is going on with these absolute fabrications about armed gangs running the streets of Hama and elsewhere. Hama has shown itself to be a model of peaceful protest. That was why our ambassador chose to go there." The French ambassador joined the US one on that day to show the French support to the victims.{{cite web|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20110709-hama-protests-bolstered-visits-usa-france-ambassadors-ford-chevallier-syria-assad |title=French and US ambassador visits bolster Hama protests - SYRIA |publisher=FRANCE 24 |date=9 July 2011 |accessdate=3 August 2011}} 7 July had seen both the French and American ambassadors to [[Syria]] toured some of the nationâs hotspots. The American ambassador Robert Ford, had travelled, with the French ambassador [[Ãric Chevallier]] to the city of Hama in what Robert Ford said was a gesture of solidarity with local protesters there.{{cite news|last=Malas |first=Nour |url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052702303406104576445864072772194.html |title=Syria Revolt Fueled by Roof Fires and Tweets - WSJ.com |publisher=Online.wsj.com |date=15 July 2011 |accessdate=31 July 2011}}[http://www.newsday.com/news/us-ambassador-visits-under-siege-syrian-city-1.3010637 ]{{dead link|date=July 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.care2.com/causes/death-squads-besiege-syrian-city-of-homs.html#ixzz1Ti3PwSxx |title="Death Squads" Besiege Syrian City of Homs (VIDEO) | Care2 Causes |publisher=Care2.com |date= |accessdate=31 July 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.care2.com/causes/death-squads-besiege-syrian-city-of-homs.html |title="Death Squads" Besiege Syrian City of Homs (VIDEO) | Care2 Causes |publisher=Care2.com |date= |accessdate=31 July 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.channel4.com/news/syrian-tank-assault-on-hama-kills-45 |title=Syrian tank assault on Hama 'kills 95' |publisher=Channel4.com |date= |accessdate=31 July 2011}} On 8 July, more tanks were deployed around the outskirts of Hama, as part of a strengthening blockade, following protests involving an estimated 500,000 people the previous weekend. It has been estimated that up to 350,000 of the city's 700,000 population have taken part in many of the protests{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/syria/8673547/Syria-dozens-dead-as-Assad-troops-launch-major-tank-offensive.html |title=Syria: dozens dead as Assad troops launch major tank offensive |publisher=Telegraph |date=25 July 2011 |accessdate=31 July 2011 |location=London |first=Adrian |last=Blomfield}} ===Ramadan events=== ====29â30 July==== Over 500,000 citizens had rallied in the city on 29 July, following Muslim prayers in which a pro-rebel cleric told the congregation "the regime must go".{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/08/20118153040657423.html |title=Deadly Syrian crackdown continues - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2 August 2011}} Local support for the Assad regime had imploded by 30 July in both [[Homs]], [[Deir ez-Zor]] and [[Hama]]. President Assad sent his "Terror Buses" packed with private [[Alawite]] militia and party loyalists into Hama on 30 July.{{cite web|author=Meld je aan of registreer je om een reactie te plaatsen! |url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QQfasMhwbLk&NR=1 |title=âªSyria - Assad Terror Buses invade Hama - Alawite Militia and Tanks assault City 7-31-11â¬â |publisher=YouTube |date=8 June 2011 |accessdate=2 August 2011}} ====31 July==== [[File:Ramadan Massacre.gif|thumb|Ramadan Massacre by [[Carlos Latuff]].]] On the eve of [[Ramadan]], Syria witnessed the bloodiest day in its 139-day uprising against the single-party regime, in which the [[Alawi]]-run government has allegedly targeted [[Sunni]], [[Druze]] and [[Christian]] groups from across the country.{{cite web|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/region/syria/ramadan-eve-massacre-in-syria-1.845638 |title=Ramadan eve massacre in Syria |publisher=gulfnews |date= |accessdate=2 August 2011}} Abdel Rahman of the Britain-based [[Syrian Observatory for Human Rights]] said on 31 July that Syrian security forces launched an offensive at 5:00 am (0200 GMT) on [[Muadhamiya]], to the north, then encircled Hama shortly afterwards.{{cite web|author=HULIQ |url=http://www.huliq.com/1/syria-army-950-oppositionists-international-community-stays-silent |title=Syria: Army kills 95 oppositionists as international community stays silent |publisher=Huliq.com |date= |accessdate=2 August 2011}} In a separate incident on the same day, political prisoners attempted to mutiny in Hama's central prison, to which security forces responded with live ammunition. The death toll in the prison is unknown.{{cite web|author= |url=http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/08/02/160464.html |title=Hama residents defy siege, shelling to pray in the open |publisher=English.alarabiya.net |date= |accessdate=3 August 2011}} The state news agency reported that eight policemen were killed in clashes in Hama.{{cite web|last=Yacoub |first=Khaled |url=http://www.thestarphoenix.com/story_print.html?id=5187856&sponsor= |title=Syrian tanks bombard residential areas of Hama |publisher=Thestarphoenix.com |date= |accessdate=3 August 2011}} The government has blamed much of the violence on terrorists and militants, who it says have killed hundreds of security personnel.{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/UN-Mulls-Syrian-Violence-as-Government-Crackdown-Continues-126582458.html |title=UN Debates Resolution Condemning Syria As Unrest Continues|publisher=Voanews.com |date=20 August 2009 |accessdate=2 August 2011}} At least 136 people have died, over 100 in Hama alone, and 19 in [[Deir ez-Zor]]. Hundreds more have been wounded. The crackdown was the most intense of the [[2011 Syrian uprising]] thus far, with over 2200 protesters dead since 15 March.{{cite web|author=AFP 31 July 2011 (2 days ago) |url=http://www.dawn.com/2011/07/31/syrian-army-kills-at-least-95-in-hama-activist.html |title=Syrian army kills at least 95 in Hama: activist|publisher=Dawn.Com |date= |accessdate=2 August 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43295395/ns/world_news-mideast_n_africa/t/syria-says-forces-killed-northern-massacre/ |title=Syria says 120 forces killed in 'massacre'|publisher=MSNBC |date=8 February 2011 |accessdate=2 August 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/07/201173143432348733.html |title='Scores dead' as Syrian tanks storm Hama city â Middle East â Al Jazeera English |publisher=English.aljazeera.net |date= |accessdate=3 August 2011}} One Hama resident, a doctor who did not want to be identified for fear of arrest, told [[Reuters]] that tanks were attacking Hama from four different directions and "firing randomly". Another resident said snipers had climbed onto the roofs of the state-owned electricity company and the main prison, and that electricity had been cut in eastern neighbourhoods.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/07/201173143432348733.html |title='Scores dead' as Syrian tanks storm Hama city - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2 August 2011}} Syrian government tanks also fired on [[mosques]] where the loudspeakers broadcast, "Allah Akbar".{{cite web|last=Ben |first=Tzvi |url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/146245 |title=New Videos: Syria Tank Fire|publisher=Israel National News |date=8 January 2011 |accessdate=2 August 2011}} A [[United Nations Security Council]] resolution condemning Syria was proposed by [[Russia]] and the Security Council met on the night of 31 July to debate the situation in Syria.{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/syria/8675593/Syria-Bashar-al-Assads-tanks-renew-assault-on-Hama.html |title=Syria: Bashar al-Assad's tanks renew assault on Hama |publisher=Telegraph |date=8 February 2011 |accessdate=2 August 2011 |location=London |first=Adrian |last=Blomfield}} Syrian dissidents claimed that the tank assault on Hama on 31 July, in which 84 people had died, was an attempt to pacify and regain control of the city ahead of Ramadan and to avert protests during the holy month.{{cite web|author=Reuters (7 hours ago) Today |url=http://www.dawn.com/2011/08/02/syrias-assad-embarks-on-path-of-no-return.html |title=Syriaâs Assad embarks on path of no return |publisher=Dawn.Com |date= |accessdate=2 August 2011}} ====1 August==== Syrian security forces continued to bombard Hama on 1 August. Many of Hama's residents braved the obvious danger to head to mosques for dawn prayers. As they emerged onto the streets, the shelling resumed. Three worshipers were struck down and killed, while a fourth was shot dead by a sniper as he got into his car, opposition activists said. Tank shells struck residential buildings in the suburbs of al-Qousour and Al-Hamidiya. "The tanks are firing at random," one resident said. "They don't care who they hit. The aim seems to be to kill and terrify as many people as possible." "The number of those wounded is huge and hospitals cannot cope, particularly because we lack the adequate equipment," said Hama hospital worker, Dr Abdel Rahman. "It seems strange that the international community seems to care less about the people of Hama than the people of Benghazi," said Omar, a rebel activist in Damascus. The death toll in Hama and Homs was reportedly âslightly enlargedâ according to the local governorate's sources.[http://www.wilsherline.net.uk/news/arabworld/Srya/ hama -and -Homs âdead- reportedly â enlarged -188592.html#ixzz1637JT0E8] Government tanks also moved in on the eastern town of Albu Kamal. In the nearby city of Deir al-Zour, had witnessed upwards to 29 over that weekend. Activists and witnesses said at least 24 civilians were killed in attacks on several cities, including Hama, on 1 August. Later that day, The European Union imposed travel bans on five more military and government officials and extended sanctions against Assad's government, including Syrian [[Defence Minister]] [[Ali Habib Mahmud]]. ====2 August==== The [[UN]]âs security council met to discuss the situation in Syria on 2 August. The [[United States|US]], [[UK]] and [[France]] wanted to formally condemn [[Syria]], but [[Russia]] and [[PRC|China]] were afraid that "it could be used as a pretext for military intervention in Syria".{{cite news|author=Lizzy Davies, Nour Ali and agencies |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/aug/02/syria-deaths-un-condemnation |title=Syria deaths continue as UN considers condemnation |publisher=Guardian |date= 2 August 2011|accessdate=2 August 2011 |location=London}}{{cite web|last=Derhally |first=Massoud A. |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-08-02/europe-submits-new-draft-un-resolution-condemning-syria-s-assad.html |title=Syria Targets Hama as EU Seeks Condemnation |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=2 August 2011}} On 2 August, Syrian dissident [[Radwan Ziadeh]] asked US [[Barack Obama|President Barack Obama]] and US Secretary of State [[Hillary Clinton]] to demand [[Bashar al-Assad|President Bashar al-Assad]] to step down.{{cite web|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5huuALRdu6Oz8G29gFEYtYc77a12w?docId=CNG.94252455dbfeae20a34e42556bbc9473.361 |title=AFP: Syrian dissidents ask Obama to demand Assad step down |publisher=Google.com |date= |accessdate=2 August 2011}} ====3â4 August==== By the morning 3 August 2011, the city was under nearly continuous gunfire since the early hours of the morning and by midday Syrian army tanks stormed through rebelâs barricades in city of Hama, occupying a central square. A post on the [[Syrian Revolution Facebook page]] read "The army is now stationed in [[Assi Square]]," and "The heroic youths of [[Hama]] are confronting them and banning them from entering neighborhoods."{{cite news |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/04/world/middleeast/04syria.html |title=Syria Sends In Tanks to Storm Center of Rebellious City |first=Nada |last=Bakri |first2=Rick |last2=Gladstone |newspaper=New York Times |date=3 August 2011 }} The water, electricity and all communications in [[Hama]] and its surrounding villages and towns had been cut off, according to nearby online posts on social networking sites. The accounts could not be independently confirmed because the Syrian government banned foreign journalists from entering the country to report. Shaam, an online video channel that is aligned to the protest movement, posted a video dated 3 August that showed at least one tank attacking a neighbourhood that the narrator said was Hayy al-Hader in Hama; heavy plumes of smoke could be seen rising in the sky. On 3 August, following the attacks, workers in Hama declared three days of general strike in memory of those killed by security forces.{{cite web|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jta59ZDMxfvBhPdfZUYR-SygjsnA?docId=CNG.2758b2fb780648c8d34ac969510e4d6a.b1 |title=AFP: Syria's Hama on strike after deadly unrest |publisher=Google.com |date=5 June 2011 |accessdate=3 August 2011}} The townâs pro-democracy movement, the [[2011 Syrian uprising#Local Coordination Committees|Local Coordination Committee]], had emailed a statement saying that shelling was especially concentrated in the [[Janoub al-Malaâab]] and [[Manakh]] districts. The group also claimed in the [[E-mail]] that civilians were being shot and houses shelled. [[Rami Abdel Rahman]], head of the [[Syrian Observatory For Human Rights]], warned that "We might be witnessing another massacre in Hama." Russiaâs [[Foreign Ministry]]'s Middle East and North Africa Department chief, [[Sergei Vershinin]], reminded the UN that his country was not "categorically" against adopting a UN resolution condemning the violence in Syria, but the Syrian Deputy Foreign Minister, [[Faisal Mekdad]] urged India to ignore Western "propaganda" if there was a vote over it in the Security Council.{{cite web|url=http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/russia-ready-to-condemn-syria/441516.html#ixzz1TyVT80L1 |title=Russia Ready to Condemn Syria|publisher=The Moscow Times |date= |accessdate=3 August 2011}} A total of 200 were killed in Hama by 4 August. ==International reactions== {{see also|International reactions to the 2011 Syrian uprising}} ===Supranational organisations=== * {{flag|UN}} The [[Security Council]] passed a resolution that "condemns widespread violations of human rights and the use of force against civilians by the Syrian authorities." on 4 August. * {{flag|European Union}} The European Union imposed travel bans on five more military and government officials and extended sanctions against Mr Assad's ruling clique on 1 August.{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/syria/8675593/Syria-Bashar-al-Assads-tanks-renew-assault-on-Hama.html |title=Syria: Bashar al-Assad's tanks renew assault on Hama |publisher=Telegraph |date= 1 August 2011|accessdate=4 August 2011 |location=London |first=Adrian |last=Blomfield}} ===States=== * {{flag|Germany}} -The chairman of the German government's committee on foreign relations declared that there should be a global boycott of Syrian gas and oil exports with the aim to pressure Syria into ending its violence against protesters.Al Jazeera Syria Live Blog. [http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/syria-8 August-2011-1232|Monday, 8 August 2011 - 12:32] Meanwhile, on the same day (8 August), a German government spokesman declared that if Assad continues to reject dialogue and resort to violence, the Syrian government will lose its legitimacy.Al Jazeera Syria Live Blog. [http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/syria-8 August-2011-1428|Monday, 8 August 2011 - 14:28 Entry] * {{flag|Italy}} â Foreign Minister [[Franco Frattini]] called the events in Hama "a horrible act of violent repression against protesters."{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2011/1 August/International-condemnation-of-Syrian-atrocities.ashx#axzz1Tj37fkq3 |title=International condemnation of Syrian âatrocitiesâ|publisher=The Daily Star |date= |accessdate=4 August 2011}} * {{flag|Lebanon}} â Former Prime Minister and leader of the [[March 14 alliance]] [[Saad Hariri]] condemned what he called a "massacre" and the "bloody murders" that he said the Syrian people endure.{{cite web|url=http://www.nowlebanon.com/NewsArticleDetails.aspx?ID=296186 |title=Lebanon news - NOW Lebanon -Hariri condemns "massacre" in Syriaâs Hama |publisher=NOW Lebanon |date=31 July 2011 |accessdate=4 August 2011}} * {{flag|Russia}} - On 1 August, the [[Kremlin]], which has been a Syrian ally, in the person of President [[Dmitri A. Medvedev]] strongly condemned the regime's actions in Hama, calling them "unacceptable." * {{flag|Turkey}} - [[President of Turkey|President]] [[Abdullah GÃ¼l]] expressed horror over Syrian security forces' use of heavy weapons, including tanks, to quell civilian protests. "It's impossible to remain silent in the face of events visible to everyone. I urge the Syrian administration to stop violence against people and to carry out reforms to build the country's future on the base of peace and stability. We cannot remain silent and accept a bloody atmosphere," GÃ¼l said.{{cite web|url=http://www.todayszaman.com/newsDetail_getNewsById.action?newsId=252393 |title=Syrian assault on Hama horrifies Turkish president |publisher=Today's Zaman |date=1 August 2011 |accessdate=3 August 2011}} * {{flag|UK}} - A press release from the British Prime Ministerâs office requested that President Bashar-al Assad 'should reform or step aside' on the noon of 1 August.{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/syria/8675068/Syria-No-10-says-President-Bashar-al-Assad-should-reform-or-step-aside.html |title=Syria: No 10 says President Bashar-al Assad 'should reform or step aside' |publisher=Telegraph |date= 1 August 2011|accessdate=4 August 2011 |location=London |first=Christopher |last=Hope}} :Foreign Secretary [[William Hague]] condemned the attack later that day,{{cite news|author=3:00PM BST 31 July 2011 |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/syria/8673501/Syria-William-Hague-condemns-shocking-violence.html |title=Syria: William Hague condemns 'shocking' violence |publisher=Telegraph |date= 31 July 2011|accessdate=31 July 2011 |location=London}} but said that that any military action was not even "a remote possibility" and "There is no prospect of a legal, morally sanctioned military intervention". * {{flag|United States}} â [[President of the United States|President]] [[Barack Obama]] said the reports from Hama were horrifying and demonstrated the true character of the Syrian regime. "Once again, President Assad has shown that he is completely incapable and unwilling to respond to the legitimate grievances of the Syrian people," he said. He said he was appalled by the government's use of "violence and brutality against its own people".{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-14360027 |title=Syria unrest: Barack Obama condemns 'brutal' Hama raid |publisher=BBC |date=30 June 2011 |accessdate=4 August 2011}} President Obama also vowed to diplomatically isolate president Bashar al-Assad as various human rights groups said that Syrian forces killed nearly 140 people in Syria on 31 July, including 100 when the army stormed the flashpoint city of Hama.{{cite web|url=http://www.skynews.com.au/world/article.aspx?id=644992&vId= |title=Obama vows to isolate Syria's Assad |publisher=Sky News |date= |accessdate=31 July 2011}} ==See also== * [[Siege of Aleppo (1980)]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{2011 Syrian uprising}} {{DEFAULTSORT:2011 Syrian Uprising}} [[Category:Arab Spring by country|Syria]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2011]] [[Category:Politics of Syria]] [[Category:Protests in Syria]] [[Category:2011 in Syria|Protests]] [[Category:2011 Syrian protests| ]] [[ar:Ø§Ø¬ØªÙØ§Ø­ Ø­ÙØ§Ø© 2011]] [[ms:Kepungan Hama]]
